children.subject: Don't be hard on yourself too for not recruiting yet. It's pretty insane for students to focus a semester on learning from classes, doing hw/projects, staying healthy with exercise/sleep/socializing, growing and dealing with the struggles of being a kid in college, AND preparing + doing interviews for companies that, at times, seem to arbitrarily reject people.

Honestly Farid, you're just pushing it too far. He never asked for any psychological advice; all he was asking was for some quantitative/qualitative judgments about his question/concern. I appreciate your efforts in trying to provide psychological help to people in this forum but please keep in mind that this is not the Tang Center Piazza. Thanks!
^(pronoun assumed to be he, sorry for that)
I have no problem with it. Part of this forum is for students to help each other however we can, I'd say this falls under that
I would like to strongly disagree with the above anon, I love the posts Farid has made in this forum and this one is no exception.
I actually really enjoy Farid's comments. Always positive. Keep it up!
EECS is psychological just as much as it is quantitative and qualitative.
Farid's posts always make me feel a bit better <3
:) Thanks ya'll. Really happy to hear these posts are helping

I was going to write a detailed response on whether companies recruit fall/spring etc but I think someone else could probably provide more stats. I'll simply say this:

If you don't get an internship this summer, you'll be fine. You'll still get a job post-grad as long as you improve resume, skills, and interview prep. I'm not going to make any assumptions, but if I had to guess, i'd say you're afraid of the consequences not getting an internship, and probably one that is prestigious and will help you grow.

With that being said, whether you choose to recruit now or spring, you'll be great either way. More companies recruit in fall, many companies still recruit in Spring. It's always better to recruit early, but it's not the only way to get a great internship.

history.content: Well, its quite obvious that the more time you put in for something, the chances that you will succeed are higher. But that being said, in my opinion, most of the big/famous companies (Big 4 and some of the others) tend to do *majority* of their recruiting in the Fall (though I've had friends who have gotten offers from those companies in the Spring too, so not all hope is lost), while the others (and this includes THE majority, without a doubt) focus on intern hiring in the Spring (they do full-time hiring in Fall). So whether or not you're at a disadvantage depends on where you want to work..

Well, its quite obvious that the more time you put in for something, the chances that you will succeed are higher. But that being said, in my opinion, most of the big/famous companies (Big 4 and some of the others) tend to do *majority* of their recruiting in the Fall (though I've had friends who have gotten offers from those companies in the Spring too, so not all hope is lost), while the others (and this includes THE majority, without a doubt) focus during Spring. So whether or not you're at a disadvantage depends on where you want to work at..

I'm curious about the distinction between fall vs spring recruiting in terms of looking for a summer internship.  From others' experience or from any statistics are there more opportunities during one period or the other?  Does fall lean more towards jobs offerings / would companies more likely to recruit for both jobs and internships at the same time?  

This past month I haven't been able to attend the tech talks, workshops, career fairs, etc... and was wondering if there was any disadvantage to putting off recruiting until spring and avoid stretching myself too thin.  

Thanks for any advice / perspectives!
history.subject: Fall vs Spring Recruiting?
